W.A. Spitzer,"Let me begin by saying that I grew up in farm country (cash grain - corn/soybeans) and I own farm land and annually receive farm subsidy payments. I would make a few points. First, most of the people who expound about farmers and farming have no idea what they are talking about. Second, I have heard about giant farms who receive huge subsidies all my life, so I presume it must be true, but it simply doesn't exist in the corn/soybean area I am familiar with. Third, there have been dramatic boom/bust cycles in crop prices the past few years, but this has been driven by speculators in the commodities markets, and currency manipulation (China). Fourth, farm products such as corn and soybeans are one of the few items that this country still exports in large amounts, so you had better be careful what you do. Finally, having said that, there has not been a recession in farm country - the farmers are doing quite nicely, and there is no reason that crop payments for corn and soybeans should continue.",farm W.A. Spitzer,"Let me begin by saying that I grew up in farm country (cash grain - corn/soybeans) and I own farm land and annually receive farm subsidy payments. I would make a few points. First, most of the people who expound about farmers and farming have no idea what they are talking about. Second, I have heard about giant farms who receive huge subsidies all my life, so I presume it must be true, but it simply doesn't exist in the corn/soybean area I am familiar with. Third, there have been dramatic boom/bust cycles in crop prices the past few years, but this has been driven by speculators in the commodities markets, and currency manipulation (China). Fourth, farm products such as corn and soybeans are one of the few items that this country still exports in large amounts, so you had better be careful what you do. Finally, having said that, there has not been a recession in farm country - the farmers are doing quite nicely, and there is no reason that crop payments for corn and soybeans should continue.",national security,A4647-P,farm products,2,4,22290,2878785,"[[""let"", ""begin"", ""saying"", ""grew"", ""farm"", ""country"", ""cash"", ""grain"", ""corn"", ""soybeans"", ""farm"", oretez,"(commenting mostly because I'm at least as appalled by the overall tenor of NYTs so called 'debate' on this as I am by Reality TV itself. Majority of selected commentators read as if they are days away from pitching High Concept Unscripted Fiction Ideas to the storied money people. Demonstrating, as if it needed to be demonstrated, the adage 'nothing succeeds like success!' or perhaps that you'll never go broke underestimating the intelligence of US mass audience)",reality shows,A2560-P,reality shows,2,4,22292,7447876,"[[""commenting"", ""mostly"", ""'m"", ""least"", ""appalled"", ""overall"", ""tenor"", ""nyts"", ""called"", ""debate"", ""reality"", ""tv""], [""majority"", ""selected"", ""commentators"", ""read"", ""days"", ""away"", ""pitching"", ""high"", ""concept"", ""unscripted"", ""fiction"", ""ideas"", ""storied"", ""money"", ""people""], [""demonstrating"", ""needed"", ""demonstrated"", ""adage"", ""nothing"", ""succeeds"", ""like"", ""success""], [""perhaps"", ""'ll"", ""never"", ""go"", ""broke"", ""underestimating"", ""intelligence"", ""us"", ""mass"", ""audience""]]","[[""VBG"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""RBS"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNPS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""VBD"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""IN"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",commenting mostly 'm least appalled overall tenor nyts called debate reality tv. majority selected commentators read days away pitching high concept unscripted fiction ideas storied money people. demonstrating needed demonstrated adage nothing succeeds like success. perhaps 'll never go broke underestimating intelligence us mass audience,"[""male"", ""dominance""]",male dominance,0,0;;;;
Jack Robinson,"Comments are a useful and frequently informative part of online news;" they should be encouraged but much more closely monitored. For openers
post: commenters should be allowed only one comment per article to avoid these ubiquitous back and forth
ori_topic: witless arguments which often clog the comments section. Obscene
ori_id: vulgar and personal attacks should be edited out
new_topic: but care must be exercised. Many subjects almost demand strong comments which some may find offensive
label: but do not really cross the line. Some are clearly at the far left
text: but important points of view. In addition
pos_text: many articles and editorials contain claims that are either wrong or at best distorted
text_s: despite usually high standards of editorial review. Comments are essential for correcting these problems. Some blogs
topic: like Prof Juan Cole usually contain thoughtful
topic_str: informed and useful information. Others seem to call forth the the worst forms of trolls
column17: I believe can correct the abuses and allow a very important part of the internet to thrive.""
column245: comments useful frequently informative part online news encouraged much closely monitored. openers commenters allowed one comment per article avoid ubiquitous back forth witless arguments often clog comments section. obscene vulgar personal attacks edited care must exercised. many subjects almost demand strong comments may find offensive really cross line. clearly far left right extreme often bring ignored important points view. addition many articles editorials contain claims either wrong best distorted despite usually high standards editorial review. comments essential correcting problems. blogs like prof juan cole usually contain thoughtful informed useful information. others seem call forth worst forms trolls bullys idiots haters. proper monitoring believe correct abuses allow important part internet thrive

author: Lisa Evers,"If home captivity is the issue, then how to explain kids being glued to their screens (and parents allowing and sometimes even encouraging it, in order to free up their own supervising responsibilities) in cars, at restaurants, walking down the street, while on holiday with their families, etc??",teenagers,A5237-P,kids being glued to their phone screens,2,4,22294,15508810,"[[""home"", ""captivity"", ""issue"", ""explain"", ""kids"", ""glued"", ""screens"", ""parents"", ""allowing"", ""sometimes"", ""even"", ""encouraging"", ""order"", ""free"", ""supervising"", ""responsibilities"", ""cars"", ""restaurants"", ""walking"", ""street"", ""holiday"", ""families"", ""etc""]]","[[""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""FW""]]",home captivity issue explain kids glued screens parents allowing sometimes even encouraging order free supervising responsibilities cars restaurants walking street holiday families etc,"[""bland"", ""food""]",bland food,0,0;;;;

fancynancy93,"I would think it would depend on the individual student. My son and my grandson have both taken courses on-line and have done very well!! Perhaps as there are less distractions, working at their own pace and on a time when they are more receptive to learning. They might miss the interaction physically..but...the plus outweighs the minisus. MJT,"The drug war and racism started this war. Throw in the media, movies, self serving prosecutors, politicians, and welcome to America. There are too many police. Fueled by public fear, all these agencies are bleeding us dry and emptying our wallets. We spend trillions on healthcare, and probably our greatest health issue is handed over to the police to solve. Talk about the dark ages. Clean up the drug issue and shrink the police.",police,A4459-P,police,2,4,22297,14660940,"[[""drug"", ""war"", ""racism"", ""started"", ""war""], [""throw"", ""media"", ""movies"", ""self"", ""serving"", ""prosecutors"", ""politicians"", ""welcome"", ""america""], [""many"", ""police""], [""fueled"", ""public"", ""fear"", ""agencies"", ""bleeding"", ""us"", ""dry"", ""emptying"", ""wallets""], [""spend"", ""trillions"", ""healthcare"", ""probably"", ""greatest"", ""health"", ""issue"", ""handed"", ""police"", ""solve""], [""talk"", ""dark"", ""ages""], [""clean"", ""drug"", ""issue"", ""shrink"", ""police""]]","[[""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNP""], [""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""PRP"", ""JJ"", ""VBG"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""]]",drug war racism started war. throw media movies self serving prosecutors politicians welcome america. many police. fueled public fear agencies bleeding us dry emptying wallets. spend trillions healthcare probably greatest health issue handed police solve. talk dark ages. clean drug issue shrink police,"[""library""]",library,1,0;;;;

p p s safler,"I am fully insured on my own and help finance Obamacare too. And I don't regret. Such obligations are imperative for a civilized society and a nation. These obligations pale in comparision with,( like all citizens do),the benefits, advantages and rights I enjoy at the same time. In fact, what I want is a far less complicated, straight-forward, far more liberal and universally applicable health care system that is at least comparable to what are obtaining presently in France,UK and Scandinavia.I don't mind the personal costs,no one should, I believe.It is the basic minimum that any nation should render to its citizens.And it could prove to be quite cheaper than whatever provided by any insurance company and far more efficient, if wisely administered. Anyway, I personally believe, ofcourse buttressed by my own calculations and ratified by my intellectual friends, that the rich are indeed the free loaders in any society, extracting far higher benefits from it than what they themselves contribute.But they make the maximum noise and grossly distort the reality for denying the middle class and the poor what they richly deserve-- through rational logic and by canons of progressive civilizations.",obamacare,A1468-P,obamacare,2,4,22301,10098012,"[[""fully"", ""insured"", ""help"", ""finance"", ""obamacare""], [""n't"", ""regret""], ad,"I support efforts aimed at improved understanding and better relations between muslims and non-muslims. p,"The penmanship my children (now ages 10 and 13) have been taught in school will suffice. It is neat, efficient and legible. There is no need to require them to become proficient in a second, archaic form of handwriting. Requiring children to learn how to read and write cursive at this point in history seems about as useful as requiring them to learn Fraktur or calligraphy. Once elementary school children have mastered standard penmanship a more effective use of school time would be to provide instruction and practice in using a keyboard.",students,A3691-P,students,2,4,22303,8891745,"[[""penmanship"", ""children"", ""ages"", ""10"", ""13"", ""taught"", ""school"", ""suffice""], [""neat"", ""efficient"", ""legible""], [""need"", ""require"", ""become"", ""proficient"", ""second"", ""archaic"", ""form"", ""handwriting""], [""requiring"", ""children"", ""learn"", ""read"", ""write"", ""cursive"", ""point"", ""history"", ""seems"", ""useful"", ""requiring"", ""learn"", ""fraktur"", ""calligraphy""], [""elementary"", ""school"", ""children"", ""mastered"", ""standard"", ""penmanship"", ""effective"", ""use"", ""school"", ""time"", ""would"", ""provide"", ""instruction"", ""practice"", ""using"", ""keyboard""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""CD"", ""CD"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""VBG"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN""]]",penmanship children ages 10 13 taught school suffice. neat efficient legible. need require become proficient second archaic form handwriting. requiring children learn read write cursive point history seems useful requiring learn fraktur calligraphy. elementary school children mastered standard penmanship effective use school time would provide instruction practice using keyboard,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,0;;;;

Sarah,"The top two reasons cats are turned into shelters are house soiling and aggression (biting). It is a well-known fact that declawed cats are deprived of their main form of defense (claws), and resort to biting. Additionally, it is painful for many declawed cats to dig in a litter box. Hence, house soiling. Shelters I have volunteered at have quite a few declawed cats come in due to these reasons, declawing being the source of these issues. Pet owners who want to declaw a cat should not have a cat--period. If you want to protect your furniture, do not own a cat. Cats naturally scratch. If dog owners don't want their animal to jump on their couches or beds, do they remove a dog's leg? If dog owners don't want a dog to bark, is debarking humane? It's the same thing as declawing a cat. Just don't have one.",your cat,A871-P,your cat,2,4,22305,17012077,"[[""top"", ""two"", ""reasons"", ""cats"", ""turned"", ""shelters"", ""house"", ""soiling"", ""aggression"", ""biting""], [""well"", Harry,"I find the comment section indispensable especially when reading an opinion piece in culling the purported facts with other website links, pointing out sloppy reasoning or offering an alternative opinion. John,"Mr. Perry makes a very reasonable argument, but I think there are very few Spud Webbs out there anymore. Most of the pros are probably a good 6 inches taller than they were even 20 or 25 years ago, let alone 100, so you would think raising the rim is a reasonable alternative. Peter B,"As a restaurant owner & operator the idea of selling reservations is problematic, made only worse by the idea that a third party might me making money from the popularity that a restaurant has generated. But as JJ points out, the public has no problem paying less for dining during less desirable hours, why should they be opposed to paying more for prime time? We regularly pay more for better seats at events, but if the price of my menu items increased between 7 & 9 on my busiest nights, or if I charged a premium for my best tables, I would be vilified. Charging a premium for the most desired reservation times seems to be the best free-market solution, but the premium should go to the restaurant,",the new apps,A2941-P,surge mary,"This is definitely a fluff 'issue', but very entertaining. My hypothesis is that people partner best with someone who's relatively compatible on the maintenance spectrum. As a low-maintenance type of gal, the sort who can get ready for an evening out in under 20 minutes (and that includes the shower), I would not be able to tolerate a guy who had 'manny-pedis' and facials. The very idea would make me cringe. Many years ago in my 20s I went on a few dates with a guy who had more hair grooming products than I did;" it just didn't work out. I've been married 15 years now to a handsome guy who is clean but doesn't primp or spend time worrying about grey hair or wrinkles. The only scent he gives off is from his deodorant and soap
post: and that's fine by me.""
column150: definitely fluff issue entertaining. hypothesis people partner best someone 's relatively compatible maintenance spectrum. low maintenance type gal sort get ready evening 20 minutes includes shower would able tolerate guy manny pedis facials. idea would make cringe. many years ago 20s went dates guy hair grooming products n't work. 've married 15 years handsome guy clean n't primp spend time worrying grey hair wrinkles. scent gives deodorant soap 's fine

author: Rev. Karen Tudor,"In our community, the most elegant, welcoming and practical buildings are our libraries. In the 9 years I have lived here, two libraries have been built and one redesigned and refurbished. Like the comments about the need for internet access among the poor, libraries ARE so much more. They have become a cultural, community hub for education, community activism, art, music, video and social interaction. One library has attracted the local gardening society to create and maintain a butterfly garden with many native plants that are marked for people to learn about them. Another group has offered to create a meandering walking path around the expanse of the building for reflection and a chance to walk in beauty outdoors. In many ways, I see our libraries becoming a sort of secular ministry -- feeding the souls as well as the minds of people. They are far from obsolete -- they are becoming more relevant and essential than ever before!",libraries,A1615-P,libraries,2,4,22312,7955845,"[[""community"", ""elegant"", ""welcoming"", John Smith,"A SINGLE PAYOR Plan such as they have in Germany, England and France, holds the potential for being a functional alternative for the US. You don't hear great upheavals from those receiving Medicare. It works. It's imperfect. Anything human is imperfect. Nicholas,"This is from the study that this writer Christie Wilcox cited about Organic farms being less ""efficient."" ""We found crop yields to be 20% lower in the organic systems, although input of fertilizer and energy was reduced by 34 to 53% and pesticide input by 97%. Enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity found in organic plots may render these systems less dependent on external inputs."" With the reduction in energy and pesticides they seem pretty efficient to me. All organic practices are not equal. Organic systems that ""stack"" crops like growing mushrooms beneath orchards or ducks and fish being raised along side rice patties are way more ""efficient"" than conventional. Science does prove organics are healthier and safer. The irony of that recent Stanford paper is that it showed there are less antibiotic resistant bacteria on organic meat and less pesticide residue on produce. Produce grown in biologically active soil, which is achieved using organic soil building methods, does have more testable ultra-trace minerals. Scientists are only now understanding how important these minerals are to human health. The holes in Christie Wilcox's argument are far and wide.",organic food,A928-P,organic farms,2,4,22316,7091605,"[[""study"", ""writer"", ""christie"", ""wilcox"", ""cited"", ""organic"", ""farms"", sr,"Germany might want to remember that after WWII 90% of Germany's outstanding debt was forgiven. the western allies recognized that the crushing reparations imposed after WWI were a mistake and they needed Germany as an ally against the soviet union. this was to a country that started the war and murdered millions of innocent people. RB,"I personally think that any organization allowed to provide Press Cards to its employees should be required by the law to have a public section comment on its website. The least they can do is defending the freedom of speech of others, journalists need to be held accountable on that, a right without a duty is an oligarchic priviledge. They should be required to provide and sustain a space for open debate for any information they provide. Lkf,"Goofy beyond belief. Religious beliefs are just that...beliefs. To whatever degree a religious practice is benign, it should be allowed. Accordingly, we should also be able to choose to be free of religion when it impinges upon public health or well being. mingsphinx,"""One of the main pillars of Syriza's economic program is the creation of 300,000 new jobs for the unemployed under a direct public employment scheme."" As it is, many government employees do not have any meaningful assignments and you want the Greek government to hire more people? What you are actually proposing is a massive expansion of welfare payments to the unemployed in Greece except that you claim to have given these people a job and so instead of social welfare you want the world to think of it as job creation. GrammyofWandA,"I went back to school in my mid-40s and earned a PhD. As a middle-aged, overweight female in a highly competetive field, I found most internships automatically closed to me. I finally had to accept one that paid less than $200 per month--and I had to move 1000 miles from home (renting an apt.) to take it. I learned a lot, and returned home to a good career in my field (after a 2nd lowly-paid year elsewhere--but at least that covered rent). I do understand that the internship site had financial problems. But I am very much aware that I was able to take that internship ONLY because I was a married woman with a husband who worked, and money in the bank. That should not be the norm.",unpaid intenship,A460-P,unpaid intenship,2,4,22337,5445067,"[[""went"", ""back"", ""school"", ""mid-40s"", ""earned"", ""phd.""], [""middle"", ""aged"", ""overweight"", ""female"", ""highly"", ""competetive"", ""field"", ""found"", ""internships"", ""automatically"", ""closed""], [""finally"", ""accept"", ""one"", ""paid"", ""less"", ""200"", ""per"", ""month"", ""--"", ""move"", ""1000"", ""miles"", ""home"", ""renting"", ""apt""], [""take""], [""learned"", ""lot"", ""returned"", ""home"", ""good"", ""career"", ""field"", ""2nd"", ""lowly"", ""paid"", ""year"", ""elsewhere"", ""--"", ""least"", ""covered"", ""rent""], [""understand"", ""internship"", ""site"", ""financial"", ""problems""], [""much"", ""aware"", ""able"", ""take"", ""internship"", ""married"", ""woman"", ""husband"", ""worked"", ""money"", ""bank""], [""norm""]]","[[""VBD"", ""RB"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VBD"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBD""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""CD"", ""VBD"", ""JJR"", ""CD"", ""IN"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VB"", ""CD"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN""], [""VB""], [""VBD"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", "":"", ""JJS"", ""VBD"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NN""]]",went back school mid-40s earned phd.. middle aged overweight female highly competetive field found internships automatically closed. finally accept one paid less 200 per month -- move 1000 miles home renting apt. take. learned lot returned home good career field 2nd lowly paid year elsewhere -- least covered rent. understand internship site financial problems. much aware able take internship married woman husband worked money bank. norm,"[""queen"", ""elizabeth"", ""ii""]",queen elizabeth ii,0,0;;;;

SD,"Abuse of birthright citizenship is not restricted only to undocumented immigrants. ridgeguy,"I learn quite a lot from NYT comments, often and in particular from thoughtful comments by authors who think differently from me. I find them valuable. I think the Times' general level of commentary is good. This in part results from the Times' curating its comments, which filters the merely shrill or ad hominem screeds. I recognize this also introduces curatorial bias, but for me, the reduction in noise is welcome. I hope the Times continues to solicit reader commentary. Vanadias,"I urge Mr. Stankiewicz to do his due diligence--required by any good journalism major--and perform some research. Two major studies in the last decade have shown that student evaluations are wholly flawed ways of evaluating learning. In fact, there is some evidence for a negative correlation between student reviews and learning. In other words, the more students dislike a professor, the better those students do in similar classes down the road. Why? Because those professors challenge students to push past their comfort zones and rigid patterns of thinking. Oh, and if you're going to use that erroneous consumer metaphor, then at least get it right: professors are not the product--the student mind is the product, and preparing it for engagement in civil Jarvis,"While the government wants us to eat healthy, it is very true that organic foods are outrageously priced for the small amount of food we recieve. Yes, when going to McDonald's and getting 5 things off of the dollar menu you get more bang for your buck. However, that is one reason why America is in such bad shape literally and figuratively. Obviously organic products are healthier for you than genetically enhanced ones. The cows that produce the normal milk we drink are fed steroids to be able to produce more milk than naturally possible. Therefore, we are not consuming 100% pure milk. That can cut down the natural nutrients we would be recieving if everyone housed their own cow. So, this article couldn't be any more incorrect by saying that America is worse off consuming organic products. If everyone decided to trade out a bag of Lay's for some all natural vegetable chips, consumption sizes would be cut down and health could be improved.",organic food,A930-P,organic VHZ,"As an academic for more than 50 years, I say, especially around grading time, that every university should require two things: minimal competence in a (new) foreign language, and performance on a musical instrument. You can cheat or get around the requirements for all kinds of other academic subjects, but you either speak French in public, or you can't. You either play the Bach Invention, or you can't. Simple. You can't cram it, you can't cheat. Besides the obvious benefits of the learning processes in both of these activities, the study of each is a valuable exercise in integrity. Laurie C,"An incredible amount of time can be lost to technical issues with online classes (and with computers in classrooms). The discussion board doesn't open, links are broken, my browser won't open this or that page, the teacher can't find the file, we can't submit our work because the files are too big, students can't figure out how to make/open/save files, printers run out of ink, presentations disappear, and on and on and ON. One of these semesters I want to do research to see if using computers really does save time in the classroom. don,"The chef's vision, blah, blah, blah. Every so often at at otherwise decent restaurant, the chef of the moment under salts the food. Just plain and simple, they miss the mark. I understand, that happens, the food doesn't turn up on the table just as the chef intended when the dish was created. I am talking about a case in which the executive chef, were she tasting the food herself, would consider it under seasoned. In such a case when I am spending $38 on an entree, would the restaurant prefer I send it back and refuse to pay, or eat it and grumble about it on Yelp, or simply shake a little salt on it and be happy and tip well? It is the restaurant's choice. In addition, salt is not cinnamon. It is an absurd comparison. An under salted dish is unpalatable. A dish with less than optimal cinnamon is still fine.",a place at the table,A1800-P,chef executive,2,4,22354,9952772,"[[""chef"", ""'s"", ""vision"", ""blah"", ""blah"", ""blah""], [""every"", Tuvw Xyz,"Readers' comments are a boon the advertising revenue of the paper: from an advertiser's point of view, a large number of comments indicates that the paper is read by many, therefore it is a fertile ground for placing ads in it. As to who writes anonymous comments: readers like Nightwood MI 5 minutes ago, who feel threatened; people like myself
post: whose pseudonym became their alter ego; people who want to share their views with others;" and people who want to surprise or even shock the Pharisee reader by unconventional ideas.""
column120: readers comments boon advertising revenue paper advertiser 's point view large number comments indicates paper read many therefore fertile ground placing ads. writes anonymous comments readers like nightwood mi 5 minutes ago feel threatened people like whose pseudonym became alter ego people want share views others people want surprise even shock pharisee reader unconventional ideas

author: Stefan K, Germany,"""Ultimately, it might be a control thing. I want to have as much say in our guest experience as possible, even when it comes down to the salt."" Yes, it's a control thing. But I find it incredible that the cook thinks he should be able to control the customer. America can be a strange place, if your free to run around with guns, but not free to put salt on your food. Erica,"I've been host to two declawed cats while trying to find them a home (They came to me this way, it would never be my choice to do this). During their stay, one of them managed to kill two birds quite efficiently without claws. (They wiggled their way through the air conditioner). I didn't see him do it to know his methods, but I know it was him. Just last week, my toothless cat killed a bird that got in the same way. He killed it with one blow of his paw. He didn't use his claws to bring it down; just one blow and it was dead. I will only leave this piece of information
post: for I could write a book on declawing cats and the pain and problems it causes. There are plenty of safe alternatives to declawing;" people need to research
ori_topic: and learn to live with animals instead of adapting them to fit our needs.""
label: declaw
column163: 've host two declawed cats trying find home came way would never choice. stay one managed kill two birds quite efficiently without claws. wiggled way air conditioner. n't see know methods know. last week toothless cat killed bird got way. killed one blow paw. n't use claws bring one blow dead. leave piece information could write book declawing cats pain problems causes. plenty safe alternatives declawing people need research learn live animals instead adapting fit needs

author: lightbulb66,"I love national parks. Growing up in India, unspoiled green spaces were really foreign, and National Parks are America's best idea for generations to come. I visit Mt Ranier National Park several times as it is almost in my backyard. I am struck by the damage that visitors can inflict on the fragile wild flower meadows in their eagerness and zeal to enjoy the beauty. While better funding and visitor resources such as mass transportation could help, something we can all do is volunteer at a NP for a few days a year. This will go a long way in relieving the already stretched NP resources and the benefit to the volunteer citizen is priceless. Picking up trash, pulling weeks, cataloging wildflowers, roving the meadows helping visitors, etc. can help give back to our country's best idea and recharge our batteries all in one act!!",overcrowded national parks,A2966-P,overcrowded national parks,2,4,22365,18648595,"[[""love"", ""national"", ""parks""], [""growing"", ""india"", ""unspoiled"", ""green"", ""spaces"", Leah,"In our 40 and some years of marriage, we have had 9 cats, and declawed all of them. Our cats are strictly indoor cats and most of them have lived 10 plus years (One even lived to 20!) without any of the behavioral problems described in this article. Our first cat destroyed our furniture and did not respond to all the behavior modification hints in these articles. If people are not allowed to declaw, I fear even more cats will be euthanized. We love our cats, and I don't think declawing them was an awful thing.",your cat,A838-P,declaw,2,4,22367,17012250,"[[""40"", ""years"", ""marriage"", ""9"", ""cats"", ""declawed""], [""cats"", ""strictly"", ""indoor"", ""cats"", ""lived"", ""10"", ""plus"", ""years"", ""one"", ""even"", ""lived"", ""20""], [""without"", ""behavioral"", ""problems"", ""described"", ""article""], [""first"", ""cat"", ""destroyed"", ""furniture"", ""respond"", ""behavior"", ""modification"", ""hints"", ""articles""], [""people"", ""allowed"", ""declaw"", ""fear"", ""even"", ""cats"", ""euthanized""], [""love"", ""cats"", ""n't"", ""think"", ""declawing"", ""awful"", ""thing""]]","[[""CD"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""NNS"", ""VBD""], [""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""CD"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""CD"", ""RB"", ""VBD"", ""CD""], [""IN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""VBN""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NN""]]",40 years marriage 9 cats declawed. cats strictly indoor cats lived 10 plus years one even lived 20. without behavioral problems described article. first cat destroyed furniture respond behavior modification hints articles. people allowed declaw fear even cats euthanized. love cats n't think declawing awful thing,"[""birthright"", ""citizenship""]",birthright citizenship,1,0;;;;

gh,"I agree with some sort of moderation, including blocking the repeatedly abusive. There is no need for anonymity but it does help encourage the comments from insiders on various issues. ""Comments"" sections seem to me to satisfy the ""Ray Healey rule of debate"" (my dad) who said that you should not enter into an argument unless you are prepared to be persuaded. author: wcovenant,"The main reason educators argue against home schooling is because it works. It works so well, they have designed the system to work against the parents who chooses to become a primary educator to their own children. The legislators' should embrace the parent's decision and remove legislative road blocks that would hinder and disrespect a parent's unique role in their children's lives. I believe this is called progress in the right direction. One way to overcome this obstacle with sports would be a standardized test that would allow public and homeschooled students to participate in all extra curriculum activities without any bias or discriminatory practices. It works so well, they have designed the system to work against the parents who chooses to become a primary educator to their own children. The legislators' should embrace the parent's decision and remove legislative road blocks that would hinder and disrespect a parent's unique role in their children's lives. I believe this is called progress in the right direction. Geoff,"One of my favorite sections of the printed NY Times is the letters to the editor. Dan Frazier,"The Internet would be a vastly different place if we could somehow do away with anonymity. But would it actually be a better place? In our very polarized world, many people are understandably reluctant to speak out on controversial issues, unless they can do so anonymously. If we want to know what people really think, we need to let them speak anonymously. So long as there has been written communication, people have had that ability, and maybe that right. Before that, people threw rocks under cover of darkness to get their point across. I understand the temptation to demand that people use their real identities, but it seems almost impossible to do in the real world. Even if you ask for a scan of my driver's license, you can't be sure it is really my license, or be sure that it has not been altered.",comment sections,A2764-P,comment ETC,"It may have made sense once upon a time but not anymore. I am liberal thinker and I don't mean to say that we need to deport people in mass or not have systems in place to care for newborns of any status who happen to be born here. But citizenship should be a priveledge that is applied for by families or legal representation in exceptional circumstances, and it should be earned thorugh a process by which it is clear the person (or family) is well invested in our culture and economy. I have two daughters born in Switzerland, neither of whom were offered Swiss citizenship at birth because the simple fact of their birth didn't make them Swiss. Under the current system it is simply too easy to take advantage of the current law and use automatic citizenship to take more than is earned. Again, I am not saying we shouldn't be a compassionate country, and how a new system is implemented would be a lengthy, difficult task, but it definitely should change.",birthright An Ordinary American,"Single payer is the obvious solution. We have a single payer system here in the Czech Republic. I can choose my doctor. I receive good care quickly. TeamVenture,"When I went to college a decade ago, the priced i paid for a single dorm room was less than a shared off-campus room. I did live in an older building with communal bathrooms, my room was tiny with a bed, desk, dresser and a small closet. Not only that, it gave my parents peace of mind that people in my building were enrolled students, opposite gender friends aren't supposed to stay overnight and an RA on every floor. At night if I needed to go somewhere on campus and felt unsafe, I could call the university for someone to walk with me. Obviously it you cannot afford to live outside of your home, that's that but for people to claim off campus housing is cheaper and everyone does it is plain ARNP,"Hold on. Reporting concerns to police is not very effective if the police are not very well trained to respond. Very few police departments have the funds (or priorities) to provide special training for dealing with mentally ill/disturbed people. Too often mentally ill people are tasered, assaulted, or shot unnecessarily. And patients who are reported to law enforcement often feel, understandably, betrayed by the person who reports them, leading them to stop treatment--or at least stop being honest about their thoughts and feelings.","no , the laws",A1577-P,"no , the laws",2,4,22385,11912768,"[[""hold""], [""reporting"", ""concerns"", ""police"", ""effective"", ""police"", ""well"", ""trained"", ""respond""], [""police"", ""departments"", ""funds"", ""priorities"", ""provide"", ""special"", ""training"", ""dealing"", ""mentally"", ""ill"", ""disturbed"", ""people""], [""often"", ""mentally"", ""ill"", ""people"", ""tasered"", ""assaulted"", ""shot"", ""unnecessarily""], [""patients"", ""reported"", ""law"", ""enforcement"", ""often"", ""feel"", ""understandably"", ""betrayed"", ""person"", ""reports"", ""leading"", ""stop"", ""treatment"", ""--"", ""least"", ""stop"", ""honest"", ""thoughts"", ""feelings""]]","[[""VB""], [""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""VB""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""RB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""VBD"", ""RB""], [""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""VBG"", ""VB"", ""NN"", "":"", ""JJS"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""]]",hold. reporting concerns police effective police well trained respond. police departments funds priorities provide special training dealing mentally ill disturbed people. often mentally ill people tasered assaulted shot unnecessarily. patients reported law enforcement often feel understandably betrayed person reports leading stop treatment -- least stop honest thoughts feelings,"[""modern"", ""men""]",modern men,1,0;;;;

Vanadias,"This reads like parody. Rate My Professors is an organized venue...with a chili pepper icon to evaluate professors' hotness, a techno-bureaucratic set of sliding scales to place people on a scale of 1-5, and rarely a serious or self-reflective comment about content, pace, or intellectual challenge. Ge real. It's a place to vent. And that venting can go either direction, too: students will sing the praise of one teacher, and assail another. Their are very few middle reviews. And why is that? Because the forum is self-selecting, and--through its rationalist design--it encourages yes or no evaluation. Is that what we want? Students who are encouraged to judge everything as either black or white?",rate professors,A4728-P,rate professors,2,4,22386,16967238,"[[""reads"", ""like"", ""parody""], [""rate"", ""professors"", ""organized"", ""venue"", ""..."", ""chili"", ""pepper"", ""icon"", ""evaluate"", ""professors"", ""hotness"", ""techno"", ""bureaucratic"", ""set"", ""sliding"", ""scales"", ""place"", ""people"", ""scale"", ""1"", ""5"", ""rarely"", ""serious"", ""self"", ""reflective"", ""comment"", ""content"", ""pace"", ""intellectual"", ""challenge""], [""ge"", ""real""], [""'s"", ""place"", ""vent""], [""venting"", ""go"", ""either"", ""direction"", ""students"", ""sing"", ""praise"", ""one"", ""teacher"", ""assail"", ""another""], [""middle"", ""reviews""], [""forum"", ""self"", ""selecting"", ""--"", ""rationalist"", ""design"", ""--"", ""encourages"", ""yes"", ""evaluation""], [""want""], [""students"", ""encouraged"", ""judge"", ""everything"", ""either"", ""black"", ""white""]]","[[""VBZ"", ""IN"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""NNPS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NFP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""CD"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""JJ""], [""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""DT"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""DT""], [""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", "":"", ""NN"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VBZ"", ""UH"", ""NN""], [""VBP""], [""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""DT"", ""JJ"", ""JJ""]]",reads like parody. rate professors organized venue ... chili pepper icon evaluate professors hotness techno bureaucratic set sliding scales place people scale 1 5 rarely serious self reflective comment content pace intellectual challenge. ge real. Mike,"The red meat and potato men are probably like my overweight, high blood pressure father, dead of a heart attack at 56. Call me crazy, but as I enter my mid 40s, I prefer to eat more vegetables, lean meat and fish, and go to the gym (or otherwise exercise), I have the feeling a lot of my peers, who also lost their fathers at what today seems like a young age, are doing the same so they can still be around when their sons reach their mid 40s instead of just being a person from history to their grandchildren talked about now and then.",modern men,A1282-P,modern men,2,4,22387,6618700,"[[""red"", ""meat"", ""potato"", ""men"", ""probably"", ""like"", ""overweight"", ""high"", ""blood"", ""pressure"", ""father"", ""dead"", ""heart"", ""attack"", ""56""], [""call"", ""crazy"", ""enter"", ""mid"", ""40s"", ""prefer"", ""eat"", ""vegetables"", ""lean"", ""meat"", ""fish"", ""go"", ""gym"", ""otherwise"", ""exercise"", ""feeling"", ""lot"", ""peers"", ""also"", ""lost"", ""fathers"", ""today"", ""seems"", ""like"", ""young"", ""age"", ""still"", ""around"", ""sons"", ""reach"", ""mid"", ""40s"", ""instead"", ""person"", ""history"", ""grandchildren"", ""talked""]]","[[""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""IN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""CD""], [""VB"", ""JJ"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""IN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""IN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBD""]]",red meat potato men probably like overweight high blood pressure father dead heart attack 56. call crazy enter mid 40s prefer eat vegetables lean meat fish go gym otherwise exercise feeling lot peers also lost fathers today seems like young age still around sons reach mid 40s instead person history grandchildren talked,"[""handwrite""]",handwrite,0,0;;;;

bkp5150,"According to the Mexican constitution, Article 30- one way for Mexican nationality is - Those born in a foreign country of Mexican parents; of a Mexican father and a foreign mother; or of a Mexican mother and an unknown father;" So if Trumps immigration plan begins with deportation for those from Mexico
post: it would in fact be deporting Mexican citizens...Mexico doesn't recognize them as American citizens. They are subject to the jurisdiction of Mexico.""
column94: according mexican constitution article 30- one way mexican nationality born foreign country mexican parents mexican father foreign mother mexican mother unknown father trumps immigration plan begins deportation mexico would fact deporting mexican citizens ... mexico n't recognize american citizens. subject jurisdiction mexico

author: Joy,"Publishing and newspapers are old industries. Publishing has fed too long from the labors of writers and readers while too seldom adding true value. Newspapers have been lean and efficient, they juat aren't capable of satisfying the demand curve of today's public. Telecommunications and transportation behaved similarly to publishing and they underwent dramatic restructuring. The music production industry is well on its way toward completing a shake up. It isn't pretty, but it is too late for publishing to control their future. Ten years ago they might have had more of a say in the direction the sector is going;" it is now pre-ordained.""

Al M,"As Truman stated so many years ago, ""It has become an operational and at times a policy-making arm of the Government. This has led to trouble and may have compounded our difficulties in several explosive areas."" Indeed, the CIA/NSA has become an all powerful, unaccountable, unconstitutional fourth wing of government in control of the Executive and running our foreign policy to the detriment of the world and of our basic rights as citizens. The CIA has always been above the law, uncontrollable and unaccountable. It is responsible for more crimes against humanity than any other organization or government, orchestrating civil wars, coups, establishing brutal dictatorships from Guatemala to Chile to Iran, training and overseeing death squads and torture around the globe. It is past time to abolish this monstrous institution along with its other faces;" NSA
post: NATO
ori_topic: USAID and put intelligence gathering back in the military with heavy
ori_id: independent oversight to prevent abuse. It is time to prosecute those responsible for international crimes and human rights abuse. It is also telling that the Times

label: didn't have former CIA analyst Ray McGovern in this conversation.""

author: meilaushi,"Right on! The watchword for any business, restaurants included, should generally be ""the customer is always right."" This is especially true with regard to tastes, and appreciation of flavors. People do not all experience the same food the same way and for an egotistic chef to imagine he has the right to determine how much salt should be put on something is ridiculous. The chef doesn't know best for everyone. So keep the salt and pepper shakers. They are the ubiquitous best flavor enhancers around--the very reason they are ubiquitous in any GOOD restaurant IMHO!",a place at the table,A1750-P,a place at the table,2,4,22395,9950813,"[[""right""], [""watchword"", ""business"", ""restaurants"", ""included"", ""generally"", ""customer"", ""always"", ""right""], [""especially"", ""true"", ""regard"", ""tastes"", ""appreciation"", ""flavors""], [""people"", ""experience"", ""food"", ""way"", ""egotistic"", ""chef"", ""imagine"", ""right"", ""determine"", ""much"", ""salt"", ""put"", ""something"", ""ridiculous""], [""chef"", ""n't"", ""know"", ""best"", ""everyone""], [""keep"", ""salt"", ""pepper"", ""shakers""], [""ubiquitous"", ""best"", ""flavor"", ""enhancers"", ""around"", ""--"", ""reason"", ""ubiquitous"", ""good"", ""restaurant"", ""imho""]]","[[""RB""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJS"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""JJ"", ""JJS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", "":"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNP""]]",right. watchword business restaurants included generally customer always right. especially true regard tastes appreciation flavors. people experience food way egotistic chef imagine right determine much salt put something ridiculous. chef n't know best everyone. keep salt pepper shakers. ubiquitous best flavor enhancers around -- reason ubiquitous good restaurant imho,"[""course"", ""online""]",course online,0,0;;;;

Naphthous,"The most insightful writing to be found in almost any article occurs in the comments. Rarely is there a significant article that is neither debunked nor enhanced by the best of the comments. I have actually started checking whether comments are enabled before I read an article - and NOT reading it if they are disabled. To me, disabling comments is a sign of weakness and/or dishonesty on the part of the author and/or the publisher. It shows a fear of dissent, a fear of being scrutinized and/or challenged. Perhaps there is an underlying insecurity about not being viewed as an authoritative voice. The solution to repugnant comments isn't to ban all comments. The solution is mechanisms (which have existed for ages) that filter, sort, and hide comments at the pleasure of the user.",comment sections,A2782-P,comment Steffan Piper,"How is bashing and belittling Amazon Publishing a debate? I fail to see anything more here than the usual 'let's smear Amazon because we must stay dogmatic about modern publishing.' Absolutely ridiculous. Referring to their editors as Chimpanzees is beyond low and trying to say that you're not is more than back-handed. And why must one automatically assume that they'll dominate the publishing industry -- especially if all they are interested in is widgets and algorithms? Inconsistent to say the least, especially if everyone else is so damn good. Seriously biased article and extremely flawed logic. If taking these kind of subtle but bratty gibes at Amazon makes someone feel better and gets them a few handshakes over their afternoon lunch in mid-town Manhattan, then I guess that's likely the real end result. Bashing someone for the sake of it is myopic at best and most reader's won't come away with anything but a negative point of view.",publishers,A312-P,publishers,2,4,22399,4757099,"[[""bashing"", Koyote,"The late Edward Abbey had a novel idea: allow anyone into a national park if travelling under their own steam -- walking, biking, skiing, etc. After all, getting out of the car is the best way to enjoy nature. As for the understandable complaints about children and the elderly not being able to travel in our parks under such a rule, Abbey replied that the kids will have their chances later (and we'll have preserved the parks for them), and the elderly had their chances when younger.",overcrowded national parks,A2960-P,overcrowded national parks,2,4,22400,18693740,"[[""late"", ""edward"", ""abbey"", ""novel"", ""idea"", ""allow"", ""anyone"", ""national"", ""park"", ""travelling"", ""steam"", ""--"", ""walking"", ""biking"", ""skiing"", ""etc""], [""getting"", ""car"", ""best"", ""way"", ""enjoy"", ""nature""], [""understandable"", ""complaints"", ""children"", ""elderly"", ""able"", ""travel"", ""parks"", ""rule"", ""abbey"", ""replied"", ""kids"", ""chances"", ""later"", ""'ll"", ""preserved"", ""parks"", ""elderly"", ""chances"", ""younger""]]","[[""JJ"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""FW""], [""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""MD"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJR""]]",late edward abbey novel idea allow anyone national park travelling steam -- walking biking skiing etc. getting car best way enjoy nature. understandable complaints children elderly able travel parks rule abbey replied kids chances later 'll preserved parks elderly chances younger,"[""declawing"", ""cat""]",declawing cat,1,0;;;;
S.L.,"It is impossible to get a good sampling from polls. Poll takers are like telemarketers;" they invade the privacy of our homes
post: especially when we are busiest. If I answer the phone at all
ori_topic: I am apt to be less than polite to the person who is bothering me. I have strong political opinions but the poll takers will never hear them because I don't want to answer a stranger's probing questions. What kinds of people are being sampled? I am not alone in my feelings about intrusive phone calls
ori_id: so it is none of us. Although I have had a few illegal calls on my cell phone
new_topic: those without landlines are not included in most samples. The skewed sampling is giving greater weight to the candidate whose fans are willing to be bothered by a poll. What does that say about his qualifications for the job of president? Nothing.""
label: pollings
column153: impossible get good sampling polls. poll takers like telemarketers invade privacy homes especially busiest. answer phone apt less polite person bothering. strong political opinions poll takers never hear n't want answer stranger 's probing questions. kinds people sampled. alone feelings intrusive phone calls none us. although illegal calls cell phone without landlines included samples. skewed sampling giving greater weight candidate whose fans willing bothered poll. say qualifications job president. nothing

author: asher,"Why are the Euro-zone members so reluctant to call it quits? It was a noble experiment, it had to be tried, but it failed miserably. Why keep punishing ordinary Europeans in order to save a fatally flawed idea? Let it go. Each country must return to individual currencies. Not doing so will lead to greater and greater misery which in turn will lead to violence and loss of life. It's not worth it. Time to admit that the elite economists and politicians failed Europe. Now the people of Europe must take back their lives. Get rid of the Euro and all the hateful feelings it has engendered in what had been a remarkably peaceful and prosperous group of nations.",germany,A3157-P,the euro,2,4,22402,7644790,"[[""euro"", ""zone"", ""members"", ""reluctant"", ""call"", ""quits""], [""noble"", ""experiment"", ""tried"", ""failed"", ""miserably""], [""keep"", ""punishing"", ""ordinary"", ""europeans"", ""order"", ""save"", ""fatally"", ""flawed"", ""idea""], [""let"", ""go""], [""country"", ""must"", ""return"", ""individual"", ""currencies""], [""lead"", ""greater"", ""greater"", ""misery"", ""turn"", ""lead"", ""violence"", ""loss"", ""life""], [""'s"", ""worth""], [""time"", ""admit"", ""elite"", ""economists"", ""politicians"", ""failed"", ""europe""], [""people"", ""europe"", ""must"", ""take"", ""back"", ""lives""], [""get"", ""rid"", ""euro"", ""hateful"", ""feelings"", ""engendered"", ""remarkably"", ""peaceful"", ""prosperous"", ""group"", ""nations""]]","[[""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VBZ""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""VBD"", ""RB""], [""VB"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNPS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""VB""], [""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VB"", ""JJR"", ""JJR"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""NNP""], [""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NNS""], [""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS""]]",euro zone members reluctant call quits. noble experiment tried failed miserably. keep punishing ordinary europeans order save fatally flawed idea. let go. country must return individual currencies. lead greater greater misery turn lead violence loss life. DavGreg,"No two people have the same sense of taste nor does any one person have a consistent sense of taste given variables such as response to environmental allergies and recovery from colds. To say that salt is not offered at the table is Bloomberg Nannyish at minimum and downright control freakish. I long ago sought to reduce the salt in my diet and my taste has adjusted over time, but I have not eliminated salt nor do I intend to. Most baked or roasted poultry dishes are horrible without some added salt and there are other foods that cry out for it- popcorn is a good example. Having worked in healthcare for 27 years I have no illusions about the harm that a high sodium diet can have on some people. However, it is also possible to wisely reduce salt intake and still enjoy it in some foods. As the taste is highly subjective and individual I cannot agree with Mr Sbragg.",salt,A1791-P,salt,2,4,22404,9944695,"[[""two"", ""people"", ""sense"", ""taste"", ""one"", ""person"", ""consistent"", Patricia,Only someone from a well-off family can afford to work for no pay. These unpaid internships harm the cause of social mobility. Social mobility is what keeps democracy and America strong. The possibility of forward movement what keeps Americans invested in the American dream. So I'm really against these internships in general. JMO,"What needs to happen is that insitutions of higher learning need to develop standards for internships. This should include a limit to the number of unpaid hours a worker can work in a week without triggering automatic compensation. Also companies should agree to interns representing only 5% of their workforce. The dirty little secret is that some companies are relying extensively on internships as a labor source. One of those companies is Disney, which has a good portion of its theme park workforce filled by interns. Then there must be standards for the work, flipping burgers or waiting tables are not acceptable intern experiences for college graduates.",unpaid intenship,A496-P,unpaid David Illig,"I can't think of a reason for the Queen to abdicate her solemn responsibilities. Should she become incapacitated the Privy Council has a mechanism for naming a regent. Charles should refuse the throne.. Nobody likes him. Of course, the British monarchy has evolved greatly over the past millennium or so, but historically, the monarch would have just as likely to have murdered or exiled the heir as to abdicate in his or her favor.",queen elizabeth ii,A2902-P,queen elizabeth ii,2,4,22409,9559686,"[[""ca"", ""n't"", ""think"", ""reason"", ""queen"", ""abdicate"", ""solemn"", ""responsibilities""], [""become"", ""incapacitated"", ""privy"", ""council"", ""mechanism"", ""naming"", ""regent""], [""charles"", ""refuse"", ""throne"", "".."", ""nobody"", ""likes""], [""course"", ""british"", ""monarchy"", ""evolved"", ""greatly"", ""past"", ""millennium"", ""historically"", ""monarch"", ""would"", ""likely"", ""murdered"", ""exiled"", ""heir"", ""abdicate"", ""favor""]]","[[""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""."", ""NN"", ""VBZ""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""JJ"", ""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""]]",ca n't think reason queen abdicate solemn responsibilities. become incapacitated privy council mechanism naming regent. charles refuse throne .. nobody likes. course british monarchy evolved greatly past millennium historically monarch would likely murdered exiled heir abdicate favor,"[""level"", ""playing"", ""field"", ""american""]",level playing field american,0,0;;;;

Virginia Beck, NP, CTP,"As a five year old, I watched the young Queen take up royal duties, after the death of her beloved father. In 1953, her government was still struggling with the aftermath of the wholesale destruction and devastation of Britain and the loss of a whole generation of young men....Governing a country is no easy task. It ignores the facts to imply that all she knows is horses. Having lived through some of the more catastrophic changes on this planet, political as well as economic and personal;" bringing a country back from the ruins
post: and having been forced to make some very tough decisions
ori_id: not just a few paragraphs... Her Royal Highness
label: more wisdom than all journalists combined.""
column140: five year old watched young queen take royal duties death beloved father. 1953 government still struggling aftermath wholesale destruction devastation britain loss whole generation young men .... governing country easy task. ignores facts imply knows horses. lived catastrophic changes planet political well economic personal bringing country back ruins forced make tough decisions impact millions people paragraphs .... royal highness probably wisdom journalists combined

ellen,"Most restaurant food is already too salty. I'd rather they salted their food LESS and let us control our salt at the table. I don't use table salt, myself. I lightly season my food and then if others want more salt they can have it. Salt should be treated as an adjunct. Food should be seasoned with spices. The salt is there to increase those flavors, not to be a flavor in and of itself. At least that's how it worked in my restaurant, and that's what I do at home now that I'm retired.",a place at the table,A1774-P,salt,2,4,22424,9948874,"[[""restaurant"", ""food"", ""already"", ""salty""], [""'d"", ""rather"", ""salted"", ""food"", ""less"", ""let"", ""us"", ""control"", ""salt"", ""table""], [""n't"", ""use"", ""table"", ""salt""], [""lightly"", ""season"", ""food"", ""others"", ""want"", ""salt""], [""salt"", ""treated"", ""adjunct""], [""food"", ""seasoned"", ""spices""], [""salt"", ""increase"", ""flavors"", ""flavor""], [""least"", ""'s"", ""worked"", ""restaurant"", ""'s"", ""home"", ""'m"", ""retired""]]","[[""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ""], [""MD"", ""RB"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""RBR"", ""VB"", ""PRP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN""], [""JJS"", ""VBZ"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""VBN""]]",restaurant food already salty. DemocracyNow,"This lack of pay is not limited to high school or college internships. It is found throughout the business world. People are encouraged to blog for a major media organization not for pay, but for ""the exposure,"" only to see that media organization sold to another company for hundreds of millions of dollars. Workers age 50 and over, who still have much to contribute, are thrown out of jobs in a subtle form of age discrimination and are then expected to work for free as part of their ""retraining"" to ease into a new profession that might pay thousands less in the end. Another poster on here mentioned volunteer workers who put in long hours while the heads of those charities reap huge salaries and benefits. The trend toward free labor is another indication of our moral decline. We have to take a stand. People, when you get up tomorrow morning and look at yourself in the mirror, repeat these words: ""I WILL NOT work for free.""",college students,A473-P,college students,2,4,22425,5449426,"[[""lack"", DemocracyNow,"This lack of pay is not limited to high school or college internships. It is found throughout the business world. People are encouraged to blog for a major media organization not for pay, but for ""the exposure,"" only to see that media organization sold to another company for hundreds of millions of dollars. Workers age 50 and over, who still have much to contribute, are thrown out of jobs in a subtle form of age discrimination and are then expected to work for free as part of their ""retraining"" to ease into a new profession that might pay thousands less in the end. Another poster on here mentioned volunteer workers who put in long hours while the heads of those charities reap huge salaries and benefits. The trend toward free labor is another indication of our moral decline. We have to take a stand. People, when you get up tomorrow morning and look at yourself in the mirror, repeat these words: ""I WILL NOT work for free.""",unpaid intenship,A472-P,unpaid intenship,2,4,22426,5449426,"[[""lack"", dbrea2000,"Reality check for those so far removed that have no idea what the issue is: Women come to the U.S. on temp visas or illegally to give birth in order to have the child become an American citizen. In some cases they stay, and in others they leave with the American child. Those that leave will eventually reap the benefits of American citizenship without ever contributing to it. It's become status symbol for foreign nationals to have children with the blue and gold passport. This is reality;" and I'm sure the founding fathers didn't have this in mind when the constitution was adopted.""
post: birthright citizenship
column115: reality check far removed idea issue women come u.s. temp visas illegally give birth order child become american citizen. cases stay others leave american child. leave eventually reap benefits american citizenship without ever contributing. 's become status symbol foreign nationals children blue gold passport. reality 'm sure founding fathers n't mind constitution adopted

author: Mathias Weitz,"The system is out of balance, and it's the national industries with their very different output levels which thrives this diversion. There is a lot of tax-payer money which is trying to counter this, but the money, which is on account of the governments are just peanuts. The german industry is steamrolling the rest of europe, and for this devastation everyone has to pay, first of all the german tax-payers. Just look at france, their demise is now on the lever. Where should this end ? A few countries with a workforce of 50 Mio is liable for producing the need of 350 Mio citizen ? But the main problem are political and social issues. This is a conundrum, the moral hazard - unlike the US every country is liable for their own efficiency. Germany can try to drag along the rest of europe, but one reason for a success is our global competitiveness and we may fail to maintain this - to say the european economy as whole has rightly become DoritReiss,"It's heartbreaking to think of children suffering because of denial of treatment - or protection against disease - from a religion they did not choose. We respect religious belief, but that respect should not extend to medical neglect of children any more than it extends to child sacrifice. There are limits on parental rights and religious freedom, and they should come into play when children are put at risk.",parents ' religious beliefs,A4581-P,parents ' religious beliefs,2,4,22431,14382821,"[[""'s"", ""heartbreaking"", ""think"", ""children"", ""suffering"", ""denial"", ""treatment"", ""protection"", ""disease"", ""religion"", ""choose""], [""respect"", ""religious"", ""belief"", ""respect"", ""extend"", ""medical"", ""neglect"", ""children"", ""extends"", ""child"", ""sacrifice""], [""limits"", ""parental"", ""rights"", ""religious"", ""freedom"", ""come"", ""play"", ""children"", ""put"", ""risk""]]","[[""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN""]]",'s heartbreaking think children suffering denial treatment protection disease religion choose. respect religious belief respect extend medical neglect children extends child sacrifice. limits parental rights religious freedom come play children put risk,"[""polling""]",polling,0,0;;;;

JP,"Firstly, this is a short article, Ms. Lloyd is only able to cover so much ground. For more info, read her book: Girls Like Us. Legalizing prostitution is not the answer. Someone wrote in the comments that selling your body is pathetic. It's not pathetic, it's a tragedy. And, so is buying another human being and deminishing their value down to mere flesh. Without getting into arguments about choice and consent -- Buying sex, buying slaves, selling sex, selling slave will ruin all of our humanity. Period. (Including those who stand by and do nothing.)",prostitution,A1062-P,prostitution,2,4,22432,6037231,"[[""firstly"", ""short"", ""article"", ""ms."", ""lloyd"", ""able"", ""cover"", ""much"", ""ground""], [""info"", ""read"", ""book"", ""girls"", ""like"", ""us""], [""legalizing"", ""prostitution"", ""answer""], [""someone"", ""wrote"", ""comments"", ""selling"", ""body"", ""pathetic""], [""'s"", ""pathetic"", ""'s"", ""tragedy""], [""buying"", ""another"", ""human"", ""deminishing"", ""value"", ""mere"", ""flesh""], [""without"", ""getting"", ""arguments"", ""choice"", ""consent"", ""--"", ""buying"", ""sex"", ""buying"", ""slaves"", ""selling"", ""sex"", ""selling"", ""slave"", ""ruin"", ""humanity""], [""period""], [""including"", ""stand"", ""nothing""]]","[[""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""IN"", ""PRP""], [""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""VBZ"", ""NN""], [""VBG"", ""DT"", ""JJ"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""IN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""NN""], [""VBG"", ""VBP"", ""NN""]]",firstly short article ms. lloyd able cover much ground. info read book girls like us. legalizing prostitution answer. someone wrote comments selling body pathetic. Jeff Atkinson,"""Continuing with the I.M.F.-E.U. imposed budget austerity measures risks condemning Greece to several more years of economic misery."" Austerity hasn't worked, it isn't working and it ain't gonna work in several more years. At some point, of course, the Greek economy will recover, even carrying the burden of austerity. But as Maynard Keynes wisely observed, ""In the long run we are all dead.""",greece 's,A809-P,greece 's,2,4,22433,13958896,"[[""continuing"", ""i.m.f"", "".-"", ""e.u.""], [""imposed"", ""budget"", ""austerity"", ""measures"", ""risks"", ""condemning"", ""greece"", ""several"", ""years"", ""economic"", ""misery""], [""austerity"", ""n't"", ""worked"", ""n't"", ""working"", ""ai"", ""n't"", ""gon"", ""na"", ""work"", ""several"", ""years""], [""point"", ""course"", ""greek"", ""economy"", ""recover"", ""even"", ""carrying"", ""burden"", ""austerity""], [""maynard"", ""keynes"", ""wisely"", ""observed"", ""long"", ""run"", ""dead""]]","[[""VBG"", ""NNP"", ""HYPH"", ""NNP""], [""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""TO"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""RB"", ""VBD"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ""]]",continuing i.m.f .- e.u.. imposed budget austerity measures risks condemning greece several years economic misery. austerity n't worked n't working ai n't gon na work several years. point course greek economy recover even carrying burden austerity. maynard keynes wisely observed long run dead,"[""seasoning"", ""food"", ""restaurant""]",seasoning food restaurant,0,0;;;;

Judyw,"I have bought organic food and have never noticed that it tasted any better than the non-organic variety. I just paid more for it. Organic food is found in large supermarkets, whereas better food is found in local market with local produce. Plus I never got sick from either one - more important is the country it comes from. I avoid anything from Mexico. I just think Organic food is over-hyped and over-priced. digitalartist,"I find American men to be more mainstream, more conformist than ever. I don't find anything sensitive or feminine about them at all. Bob H,Rate my Professor is essentially an internet scam to generate site traffic. I am sorry to see it getting this kind of free publicity in a serious paper like the NYT. Rate my Professor is a for-profit site. You can even post a review of someone without ever having taken a class with that person or on a class that the professor never taught. Try it. Most universities have systems for the evaluation of faculty. (I would be surprised if any do not.) They ensure that only students who actually took the class participate in the evaluation process.,rate professors,A4740-P,rate professors,2,4,22436,16969471,"[[""rate"", ""professor"", ""essentially"", ""internet"", ""scam"", ""generate"", ""site"", ""traffic""], [""sorry"", ""see"", ""getting"", ""kind"", ""free"", ""publicity"", ""serious"", ""paper"", ""like"", ""nyt""], [""rate"", ""professor"", ""profit"", ""site""], [""even"", ""post"", ""review"", ""someone"", ""without"", ""ever"", ""taken"", ""class"", ""person"", ""class"", ""professor"", ""never"", ""taught""], [""try""], [""universities"", ""systems"", ""evaluation"", ""faculty""], [""would"", ""surprised""], [""ensure"", ""students"", ""actually"", ""took"", ""class"", ""participate"", ""evaluation"", ""process""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNP"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""NNP""], [""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBD""], [""VB""], [""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""MD"", ""JJ""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",rate professor essentially internet scam generate site traffic. sorry see getting kind free publicity serious paper like nyt. rate professor profit site. even post review someone without ever taken class person class professor never taught. try. universities systems evaluation faculty. would surprised. ensure students actually took class participate evaluation process,"[""modern"", ""men""]",modern men,1,0;;;;

Sailor40,"Some people become addicted to alcohol, but after the fiasco of Prohibition, the United States learned that we were better off legalizing and controlling access to it. Gambling has been legalized in most states, and regardless of the current attempts to block it, Americans today already have access to Internet based gambling. The regulations that currently restrict the banking system from dealing with Internet gamling sites should be eliminated. Regulations should be established to protect consumers. The resulting legal activity should be taxed to pay for the necessary oversight agencies, and to provide assistance for those who can't simply enjoy gambling as entertainment and sport.",internet David Keys,"Most Americans have the same attitude about languages other than their own, as they have about those people who might speak them--fear [and eventually hate]...Although I was educated in what seems like the last ice age, instruction in foreign language began in earnest in middle school and graduating with a bachelor's degree required competency in both a classical (Latin, Greek, Hebrew) and a modern language (French, Spanish, or Italian). With all the teaching aids at our fingertips now, the old curriculum should be revived. elizabeth renant,"The only solidarity the hijab shows is with that most ancient of patriarchal male control strategies, shifting the burden of morality, family and male honor, etc., onto the shoulders of female modesty. It is no different from Orthodox Jewish married women having to cover their hair, or the in the Middle Ages married women in Europe were expected to wear a coif to cover their hair, and is nakedly an attempt to confine women's sexual nature in as small a space as possible. It stands in relationship to footbinding and to female genital mutilation, albeit at another point on the bellcurve of control of women and control of female sexuality. If you insist on sacrificing yourself on this altar to show ethnic solidarity, don't be surprised when people conclude that Islam is still stuck in the past. As Rhett Butler once famously said to Scarlett in ""Gone with the Wind"" when she refused to abandon black mourning clothes for a husband she not only didn't love, but despised, ""How closely women clutch the chains that bind them!"" Find another way to announce your religious/ethnic identity. johnny29,"As a Creative director and published author I received 15% commission on every book sold and did quite well. Today I can publish my ebook myself and of course edit it after I write it and spell check it as well. Now I can earn 70% on every ebook sold. That allows me quite a bit of leeway in promoting my ebook. Tell me more why I should use an author agent who takes a commission and a publisher who makes a lot of money from my writing? By the way, they never gave authors extra money when they submitted the manuscript electronically saving publishers money by not having to enter text into a computer from typewritten pages-they kept the savings. Entropic,"I would tend to agree: Poll results (no matter how ill formed the poll questions) create a public narrative that exists outside of any rigorous definition of reality. This is very much like the artificial Red State / Blue State divide, when in fact most states are clearly purple. But polls tell us Texas is full of tea party nuts, and Massachusetts the lair of well meaning but totally impractical socialists and Harvard pontificators. And ne'er the twain shall meet. This is, of course, a dangerous way to conduct public dialogue, and I lay a lot of the blame on the press, which refuses to call the idiocy of some of these polls out. The fourth estate needs to step back and find some voices of reason.",democracy,A3264-P,democracy,2,4,22453,16803626,"[[""would"", ""tend"", ""agree"", ""poll"", ""results"", ""matter"", ""ill"", Jim L,"I watch enough cooking competitions (on TV) to realize that 4 chefs at a table will not all agree as to the quality and complexity of the seasoning upon the palate. Now add 2 or three courses, and remove the trained palates from diners who may be there for reasons other than the chef's concoction, and you may realize that salt and pepper belong on the table to satisfy the the varying palates of those paying to dine. I like a bit of salt on my salad, especially on tomatoes or the bread which is put on the table. At home in the shaker, we use salt that has the lowest amount of sodium (approx. 280mg per serving) and we have a grinder as well. I rarely add salt without taking a bite first. I have also had dishes where I wish i could remove salt from a dish. Leave it on the table. Those with health concerns and have minimal will power, ask to have it removed from the table.",salt,A1771-P,salt,2,4,22454,9948974,"[[""watch"", ""enough"", ""cooking"", ""competitions"", ""tv"",
