Jodi Anderson,"With the costs of education FAR outpacing inflation, I wonder what these unpaid interns have to do to keep their heads above water? (Those who aren't lucky/rich enough to have parental support, that is). Of course, the price inflation of education accident. It's due to the government policy of underfunding public education. Coming from a disadvantaged background, I was simply unable afford to take on unpaid work during and after college, regardless of how much it might have helped my future career to do so. Thus I was at a disadvantage compared to peers at my college. This doesn't really sound like a level playing field, does it??? One additional point: The emphasis on internship experience on resumes allows employers an easy way to ascertain which candidates are likely to come from wealthier backgrounds...making it easier for employees to discriminate in terms of social class and race (since certain races are more likely to be represented in the disadvantaged group). Not fair. And we wonder why there are no jobs out there? Employers are filling lots of them for free.",college students,A455-P,college students,2,4,22455,5445428,"[[""costs"", ""education"", ""far"", ""outpacing"", ""inflation"", ""wonder"", ""unpaid"", Sequel,"I prefer to know how many people are responding to a Times article in a manner that would please Nazi's and racists and homophobes. I prefer to know why they think such horrifying things, and how deeply they feel about it. And I really appreciate seeing how people hasten to tell them they are seriously wrong. I don't feel that I am in any danger of absorbing horrific ideas simply by hearing them. I would call that a bogus social theory. The converse of the idea that social engineering of permissible ideas is a good thing, is that people respond better if only exposed to approved ideas. That's just as bad.",comment sections,A2752-P,comment sections,2,4,22459,18247485,"[[""prefer"", ""know"", ""many"", ""people"", ""responding"", ""times"", ""article"", ""manner"", ""would"", ""please"", ""nazi"", ""'s"", ""racists"", ""homophobes""], [""prefer"", ""know"", ""think"", ""horrifying"", ""things"", ""deeply"", ""feel""], [""really"", ""appreciate"", ""seeing"", ""people"", ""hasten"", ""tell"", ""seriously"", ""wrong""], [""n't"", ""feel"", ""danger"", ""absorbing"", ""horrific"", ""ideas"", ""simply"", ""hearing""], [""would"", ""call"", ""bogus"", ""social"", ""theory""], [""converse"", ""idea"", ""social"", ""engineering"", ""permissible"", ""ideas"", ""good"", ""thing"", ""people"", ""respond"", ""better"", ""exposed"", ""approved"", ""ideas""], [""'s"", ""bad""]]","[[""VBP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""POS"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""VB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBP""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBG""], [""MD"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""RBR"", ""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""NNS""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ""]]",prefer know many people responding times article manner would please nazi 's racists homophobes. prefer know think horrifying things deeply feel. really appreciate seeing people hasten tell seriously wrong. n't feel danger absorbing horrific ideas simply hearing. would call bogus social theory. converse idea social engineering permissible ideas good thing people respond better exposed approved ideas. ManhattanWilliam,"I think the concept of rating professors online (like just about any other form of public ratings) is ludicrous. To think that students attending a college where they are to be judged by a professor and given a grade for a class should be taken as fair and impartial in rating that professor's performance makes ZERO sense. Even worse, of course, are people who go out to eat and suddenly find themselves qualified to write for Gourmet Magazine. I read these reviews occasionally but NEVER take them seriously. Still, complaining will do nothing to stop this from occurring. Such are the times we live in and nothing is going to turn back the clock HOWEVER I, for one, think the concept is pretty repulsive and anyone or any institution that takes these ratings seriously is, by my definition, a person not to be taken seriously.",rate professors,A4739-P,rate professors,2,4,22460,16969541,"[[""think"", ""concept"", ""rating"", ""professors"", ""online"", ""like"", ""form"", Earthling,"According to the Centers for Disease Control, childhood obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. The percentage of children aged 6-11 years in the United States who were obese increased from 7% in 1980 to nearly 18% in 2012. Similarly, the percentage of adolescents aged 12-19 years who were obese increased from 5% to nearly 21% over the same period. Now, more than one-third of American children and adolescents are overweight or obese. The obesity epidemic is linked to screen time, to kids sitting on their butts looking at screens all day, to the lack of outdoor activity and exercise. Mind and body are interactive systems and without a healthy body, there can be no healthy mind. How many yougn people these days are depressed, or hyperactive, or otherwise suffering from some mental disorder --- and how many would benefit from fresh air and exercise and time in the natural world? Mr. Bergman does not even begin to address childhood and adolescent obesity in his screed based only on personal anecdote.",teenagers,A5231-P,teenagers,2,4,22461,15513413,"[[""according"", John Gunther,"Separating internships as a special class of poorly paid work seems almost pointless. If MacDonald's can't employ a cashier who's willing to work for less than minimum wage (or for free), why can ABC do it for an intern? The only reason for an exception would be if the intern is there for true training purposes and not for the employer's immediate benefit. Clearly, most interns are there to supply grunt labor, whether or not they actually get a chance to show their stuff. Also, the kind of large corporations who hire rafts of interns can certainly afford to pay them minimum wage to escape all legal scrutiny. These firms could still take comfort in knowing that minimum wage isn't nearly enough to live on.",college students,A447-P,college students,2,4,22463,5449542,"[[""separating"", ""internships"", JMATA,"Not subject to the jurisdiction of the United States suggests, for example, people born in embassies, which are extraterritorial. Jurisdiction in this context is a territorial concept: i.e. where the laws can be applied. SouthernView,"Fletcher has got it exactly right. The best solution would be for both Elizabeth and Charles to abdicate and turn the Firm over to William and Kate. But since that will not happen, let's postpone until we're left with no choice the ascension of Charles--and even worse, Camilla. The thought of boring, stuffed-shirt Charles as king for decades is bad enough, but having Camilla shoved front and center would be a nightmare come true, even without the formal title of queen. Imagine-year after year of pictures of the two puttering in their garden with their little spades and shooting grouse at Balmoral. Oh, the horror, the horror-made even worse by knowing that Will and Kate are having to lie low. Of course, knowing the media's attention will gravitate anyway toward the young and vibrant, I feel a tinge of sympathy for the sad fate awaiting Charles and Camilla.",queen elizabeth ii,A2905-P,queen Ana V.,"""Nonfiction can be frighteningly raw. While fiction comforts us with the knowledge that actors are delivering lines crafted by writers, reality television offers no protective cover. We watch reality to for entertainment that it has to offer yet is the raw that nothing can seem to conforms us. Its so contradicting with itself that it amuseses us. Reality TV makes us confront with exactly what our society has become. Many say is trash but if is trash then we must reevaluting how our society is today as a whole. If critics seems that reality TV is trash is not worth our time i beg the differ that it is. It opens our eyes of what is out there and the problems we should be dealing with instead of setting them aside to be ignore. Andrew Beggs,"I agree, owning a cat is a commitment which involves taking on a duty of care. Gwenael,"What I find regrettable is that young women in their 20's would accept rules set up by old men currently holding power in the Muslim world and men who created those rules hundreds of years ago . How Pathetic that young women who should represent the future are protecting Idiotic laws from the past . The Quran says that married women should be discrete towards other men , it never said women should be covered from head to toes. We know the rules were set up to dominate women in Muslim countries , the same way other rules were set up in Christian countries to keep women at the lower end of society . I think of all those women in Muslim countries like in Saudi Arabia , trying to have the freedom to dress the way they want and at the same time women in western countries advocating for Scarfs on Gwenael,"What I find regrettable is that young women in their 20's would accept rules set up by old men currently holding power in the Muslim world and men who created those rules hundreds of years ago . How Pathetic that young women who should represent the future are protecting Idiotic laws from the past . The Quran says that married women should be discrete towards other men , it never said women should be covered from head to toes. We know the rules were set up to dominate women in Muslim countries , the same way other rules were set up in Christian countries to keep women at the lower end of society . I think of all those women in Muslim countries like in Saudi Arabia , trying to have the freedom to dress the way they want and at the same time women in western countries advocating for Scarfs on Matthew Carnicelli,"While it's true that many unmoderated comments sections can become sewers (the NY Daily News section was an absolute cesspool...), moderated comments sections like those The Times actually make a tremendous contribution to both reader understanding of the issues and our political process. Matt P,"Mr. Lackman says Europe will not agree to end its disastrous austerity policies toward Greece for fear that they will have to do so elsewhere. That's a feature, not a bug. Austerity has been bad for Europe as a whole;" it's led directly to the third recession in 7 years
post: and the risk of a long-term stagnation far below economic potential. The defiance by Greek voters should serve as a wake-up call not just for the Irish
label: but for the Germans
type_idx: Dutch and Finns as well: austerity is killing Europe

author: Debbie D,"Voice recognition is not where it needs to be at all, especially when trying to capture back and forth across a big room. Don't have a problem with an audio record also, but have to have text. I know this is not how we are 'supposed' to think about technology, but do we want to end thousands of good paying jobs? Will,"For some reason farmers (and fisherman) view making a profit as a right. Why should the rest of us support them? Farms are no more required for national security than are supermarkets or restaurants. If those businesses can survive in a free market, so can farms. In a time when unemployment is so high and our infrastructure is crumbling, giving money to farmers is disgraceful. The fact that most subsidies actually go to large agro-business and wealthy farmers is even more galling.",farm subsidies,A4642-P,farm subsidies,2,4,22479,2879338,"[[""reason"", ""farmers"", ""fisherman"", ""view"", ""making"", ""profit"", ""right""], [""rest"", ""us"", ""support""], [""farms"", ""required"", ""national"", ""security"", ""supermarkets"", ""restaurants""], [""businesses"", ""survive"", ""free"", ""market"", ""farms""], [""time"", ""unemployment"", ""high"", ""infrastructure"", ""crumbling"", ""giving"", ""money"", ""farmers"", ""disgraceful""], [""fact"", ""subsidies"", ""actually"", ""go"", ""large"", ""agro"", ""business"", ""wealthy"", ""farmers"", ""even"", ""galling""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""PRP"", ""VBP""], [""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""NNS"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ""]]",reason farmers fisherman view making profit right. rest us support. farms required national security supermarkets restaurants. businesses survive free market farms. time unemployment high infrastructure crumbling giving money farmers disgraceful. fact subsidies actually go large agro business wealthy farmers even galling,"[""college"", ""student""]",college student,1,0;;;;

Emanuel Kataev,"I've been an intern at several places and can say that while there are educational elements to them, interns are mostly given grunt work to assist paid employees. After my experience, I have decided I will never be an intern and/or work for free again. A lot of people are fooled into believing that based on their grades and/or standing in school, there is no other way to get your foot in the door. That is not true. As a mediocre student, I was able to find a paid position where I worked, got paid, and just as well received the same educational value I would have received if I was unpaid. In my opinion, interns should receive minimum wage. Granted, they have no experience, minor if not any qualifications, and generally no practical knowledge. However, they use their limbs and their brains just as any paid employee. This would be most fair, and would certainly boost the United States economy.",college students,A491-P,college students,2,4,22481,5447530,"[[""'ve"", ""intern"", ""several"", ""places"", ""say"", Raymond,"As an American Latino I do not at all like the separation between ' us ' and everyone else. We are one nation. Why are we so quick to say Latino families should be afforded higher education? How, in this age of political correctness, is that okay? Are we going to run around wearing Brown Pride shirts next? If white folk decided to have ' white only ' forums or ' white only ' college programs that would be labeled racist and exclusionary. We Latinos separate ourselves ENOUGH by insisting on very little to zero assimilation in our communities and on being Latin in everything we say, do, read and watch. We even teach our children to shun away from saying they are Americans like its a bad thing. College is NOT a right. As such, we shouldn't to get a free ride just because we happen to speak Spanish at home. It's an archaic way of thinking and not what the American Dream is supposed to be. I do not support segregation in any form. It creates animosity and we have enough of that already. I don't agree with the all black institutions or the Nedro college fund either.",college,A4672-P,culture division,2,4,22482,17282924,"[[""american"", ""latino"", ""like"", ""separation"", ""us"", Bernie15,""" Congress should delay the law for a year...""? Tell that to my niece whose 17 month old toddler has just been diagnosed with a rare disease that will need years of medical care. Without the provisions in the new health care law, this family would be facing bankruptcy. I prefer living in a nation where we have the decency to realize that health care is a right. Obviously those who seem to be objecting to the new health care law have never faced what 30 million people face in our country every day. Bernie15,""" Congress should delay the law for a year...""? Tell that to my niece whose 17 month old toddler has just been diagnosed with a rare disease that will need years of medical care. Without the provisions in the new health care law, this family would be facing bankruptcy. I prefer living in a nation where we have the decency to realize that health care is a right. Obviously those who seem to be objecting to the new health care law have never faced what 30 million people face in our country every day. Dave,"One of the useful roles a comment sections can serve: an immediate correction mechanism from the general public when an author is demonstrably wrong on the facts. For example, another news site ran an article decrying the fact that none of the presidential candidates had bothered to pay any attention to New York's public housing projects. Within about 15 minutes of the story being released, commenters were putting up links to stories about Bernie Sanders visiting New York's public housing projects about 10 hours earlier, a rebuttal that many readers might have been unaware of had the comment section not existed. And the New York Times' centralized moderation system isn't the only way to get real legitimate debate going, with evidence and logic being thrown around (along with the occasional entertainment like parody song lyrics or poetry).",comment sections,A2847-P,comment sections,2,4,22486,18243443,"[[""one"", ""useful"", ""roles"", ""comment"", ""sections"", ""serve"", ""immediate"", ""correction"", Bob Garcia,"Rizzo gives us vague generalities about the usefulness of the CIA. Let's turn that around and ask for some demonstrable lists of vital support they have provides over the last two decades. Oh yes, and as a lawyer, Rizzo should be sure to separate the list into legal and illegal support. In other words, let's start from the premise that the CIA has been an irresponsible rogue organization and have them prove otherwise. I know, never going to happen. Glendon,"The CIA reminds me by its recent actions of the old joke, ""Military Intelligence is a contradiction in terms."" To the extent that the CIA has become militarized and lawless, (which is the real reason that the prison at Guantanemo was established, so that torture could take place without the oversight of U.S. law) it has become a detriment to the nation, and a blot on the United States' reputation. We should disband the CIA and assign its responsibilities to civilians who will obey the laws and understand the consequences of covert actions to our foreign relations. The State Department should be well up to the task. Faulty intelligence leads to lost wars and continual embarrassment for the politicians who rely on it. The CIA should have no ties to the Department of Defense, so that operations can be unfettered by a military mindset.",the c.i.a.,A725-P,the c.i.a.,2,4,22494,13651841,"[[""cia"", ""reminds"", Look Ahead,"Glad Ms Grace is no longer associated with the Medicaid Commission. But as her credentials for this debate include ""free market ideas for health care reform"", its interesting that she doesn't offer any. Must be one of those ""social welfare"" groups organized to attract tax deductible funds for GOP causes. The Manhattan study focuses only on premiums and not total HC cost. Since the actuarial value is increasing from 45% today to 80% (% of premiums paid in claims) in the individual market, its going to be a better deal by definition. Mr. Roy forgot to mention that. The young male premiums before subsidy go up so much because they are offsetting higher premiums traditionally paid by women in the ""free market"" because they have babies, even though it usually takes two. And younger people are paying more to reduce the age penalty as they get older, much like we do for Medicare. So what's a young high income male without insurance to do (not many of these, BTW) to reduce their premiums? They can buy catastrophic coverage for a small amount to cover major expenses, just as before.",obamacare,A1450-P,obamacare,2,4,22495,10098566,"[[""glad"", ""ms"", ""grace"", ""longer"", Laura S.,"The greatest treat for my 91 year old dad almost up till he died, was reading the New York Times commentary. He taught architecture and was a liberal type. Every morning he commented to me that he was impressed;" commentary was knowledgable and informative and it took all day. I was glad that he found his very own hang out where people cared about being informed citizens.""
post: comment sections
column77: greatest treat 91 year old dad almost till died reading new york times commentary. taught architecture liberal type. every morning commented impressed commentary knowledgable informative took day. glad found hang people cared informed citizens

author: Maigari,"Germany leaving the Euro now? hardly fesible given the enrmous costs involved. The Greeks, Portuguese and to some extent the Italians have been forced to make sometimes debilitating cuts just to keep the union. If Germany exits, the resulting depression will once again bring to the fore the ultra nationalists in many states and no one can predict the resultant chaos that will inevitably follow. For the time being germany ie well trapped in the euro until the crisis ebbs and then the argument to separate may in all probability ebb away also",the euro,A3162-P,germany leaving the euro union,2,4,22497,7638928,"[[""germany"", ""leaving"", ""euro""], [""hardly"", ""fesible"", ""given"", ""enrmous"", ""costs"", ""involved""], [""greeks"", ""portuguese"", ""extent"", ""italians"", ""forced"", ""make"", ""sometimes"", ""debilitating"", ""cuts"", ""keep"", ""union""], [""germany"", ""exits"", ""resulting"", ""depression"", ""bring"", ""fore"", ""ultra"", ""nationalists"", ""many"", ""states"", ""one"", ""predict"", ""resultant"", ""chaos"", ""inevitably"", ""follow""], [""time"", ""germany"", ""ie"", ""well"", ""trapped"", ""euro"", ""crisis"", ""ebbs"", ""argument"", ""separate"", ""may"", ""probability"", ""ebb"", ""away"", ""also""]]","[[""NNP"", ""VBG"", ""NNP""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN""], [""NNPS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNPS"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""MD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""RB""]]",germany leaving euro. hardly fesible given enrmous costs involved. greeks portuguese extent italians forced make sometimes debilitating cuts keep union. germany exits resulting depression bring fore ultra nationalists many states one predict resultant chaos inevitably follow. time germany ie well trapped euro crisis ebbs argument separate may probability ebb away also,"[""salt""]",salt,1,0;;;;

Teacher,"I agree with many of my fellow commenters that the NYT does an excellent job of moderating comments, and I am extremely grateful for the resources they expend to offer this service. Being able to comment has made a big difference to me as a professional --I find it an invaluable outlet. Plus, reading NYT comments generally makes me feel pretty hopeful about humanity, as a matter of fact.",comment sections,A2813-P,comment sections,2,4,22499,18247574,"[[""agree"", ""many"", ""fellow"", ""commenters"", ""nyt"", ""excellent"", ""job"", ""moderating"", ""comments"", ""extremely"", ""grateful"", ""resources"", ""expend"", ""offer"", ""service""], [""able"", ""comment"", ""made"", ""big"", ""difference"", ""professional"", ""--i"", ""find"", ""invaluable"", ""outlet""], [""plus"", ""reading"", ""nyt"", ""comments"", ""generally"", ""makes"", ""feel"", ""pretty"", ""hopeful"", ""humanity"", ""matter"", ""fact""]]","[[""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", "":"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""CC"", ""VBG"", ""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBZ"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",agree many fellow commenters nyt excellent job moderating comments extremely grateful resources expend offer service. able comment made big difference professional --i find invaluable outlet. plus reading nyt comments generally makes feel pretty hopeful humanity matter fact,"[""organic"", ""food""]",organic food,0,0;;;;

Yoda,"The new Greek govt must do 2 things. One is to negotiate a decrease (or restructuring to longer payment terms) of its debt. That is the immediate problem. The new Govt. may or may not be able to do this. That will depend on how the negotiations go with the creditors. Simultaneously, and very importantly however, Greece must undergo serious economic reforms. For example the creation of a land registry, a stop to political vote buying by politicians, a stop to corruption, the creation of an apolitical statistical service, a non-pollitcal civil servant based on merit instead of cronyism, etc. Does the new Govt show any signs of this (beyond rheteric)? Absolutely not. There are no signs that a land registry will be created, that merit will be the basis of a civil service, that a non-political statistical service will be created or that an effective tax collection agency will be set up. Hence this latter task will not be accomplished.",greece 's,A799-P,greek economic reforms,2,4,22500,13981594,"[[""new"", ""greek"", ""govt"", ""must"", ""2"", ""things""], [""one"", ""negotiate"", hen3ry,"When did having 75% of the students passing a course with a C or better become a good thing? I think that a 75% passing rate is not good. Did anyone work with these students to understand why only 75% of them passed? How much did the 75% who passed understand? Were they able to apply what they had been taught on line? I've taken online courses and they were not well designed, flexible, or conducive to having a discussion. This holds true for a set of courses I took 5 years ago and for several I've taken in the last year. Having an on line course available in conjunction with a live course would be great. Then the students can go over it to see what they've missed, ask questions if that doesn't help, and refer back to it when their notes aren't enough to recall the subject matter to mind. But exclusive reliance upon on line courses is foolish.",the best way,A2402-P,the best way,2,4,22502,3651490,"[[""75"", ""students"", ""passing"", ""course"", ""c"", ""better"", ""become"", ""good"", ""thing""], [""think"", ""75"", ""passing"", ""rate"", ""good""], [""anyone"", ""work"", ""students"", ""understand"", ""75"", ""passed""], [""much"", ""75"", ""passed"", ""understand""], [""able"", ""apply"", ""taught"", ""line""], [""'ve"", ""taken"", ""online"", ""courses"", ""well"", ""designed"", ""flexible"", ""conducive"", ""discussion""], [""holds"", ""true"", ""set"", ""courses"", ""took"", ""5"", ""years"", ""ago"", ""several"", ""'ve"", ""taken"", ""last"", ""year""], [""line"", ""course"", ""available"", ""conjunction"", ""live"", ""course"", ""would"", ""great""], [""students"", ""go"", ""see"", ""'ve"", ""missed"", ""ask"", ""questions"", ""n't"", ""help"", ""refer"", ""back"", ""notes"", ""n't"", ""enough"", ""recall"", ""subject"", ""matter"", ""mind""], [""exclusive"", ""reliance"", ""upon"", ""line"", ""courses"", ""foolish""]]","[[""CD"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RBR"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""CD"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""CD"", ""VBN""], [""JJ"", ""CD"", ""VBD"", ""VB""], [""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""CD"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""JJ""], [""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ""]]",75 students passing course c better become good thing. think 75 passing rate good. anyone work students understand 75 passed. much 75 passed understand. able apply taught line. hen3ry,"When did having 75% of the students passing a course with a C or better become a good thing? I think that a 75% passing rate is not good. Did anyone work with these students to understand why only 75% of them passed? How much did the 75% who passed understand? Were they able to apply what they had been taught on line? I've taken online courses and they were not well designed, flexible, or conducive to having a discussion. Daniel Hoffman,"Ryan Radia writes like someone who is a newbie to Android. He could get better informed by following XDA-Developers, AndroidCentral, or a similar group of people who understand Android. Mr. Radia could also visit the PlayStore and look at all the applications, like Titanium Backup, that require root access to function. App Quarantine Pro, would let you lock down crapware so that it does not run down your battery, slow your device, or spy on you. You cannot use sophisticated spyware blockers because that interferes with Google, the device manufacturers and the networks from selling your personal data. Google, the device makers, and the networks, collude to prevent people from actually owning their devices. If they really belonged to us, we would be able to install software to backup them up to an external hard-drive. We would be able to decide which applications to uninstall. We would be able to decide upon the rules applications have to follow when they are on our devices, not the ""take it or leave it"" practices we have at present.",a harmful monopoly,A1930-P,current Former Victim of Sexual Abuse,"I learned cursive in grade school back in the 80's and I haven't stopped using it since. It's a skill I am grateful I have. As kids, we took pride in our handwriting...today...I don't think kids know what a pen is. That's sad. I look at some handwriting from pretty high level professionals and it's atrocious. People don't even write whole words anymore. To me, this speaks to standards, which I believe were effectively lowered forever when spellcheck was invented. Soon the question will be asked...do children need to write at all...can't they just text the answers to their teachers? I, for one, look forward to the beautifully handwritten notes I get from friends and remember them much more than emails and text messages. Please, let's not lower the standards on handwriting too.",students,A3692-P,handwrite,2,4,22507,8892334,"[[""learned"", ""cursive"", ""grade"", ""school"", ""back"", ""80"", ""'s"", ""n't"", ""stopped"", ""using"", ""since""], [""'s"", ""skill"", ""grateful""], [""kids"", ""took"", ""pride"", ""handwriting"", ""..."", ""today"", ""..."", ""n't"", ""think"", ""kids"", ""know"", ""pen""], [""'s"", ""sad""], [""look"", ""handwriting"", ""pretty"", ""high"", ""level"", ""professionals"", ""'s"", ""atrocious""], [""people"", ""n't"", ""even"", ""write"", ""whole"", ""words"", ""anymore""], [""speaks"", ""standards"", ""believe"", ""effectively"", ""lowered"", ""forever"", ""spellcheck"", ""invented""], [""soon"", ""question"", ""asked"", ""..."", ""children"", ""need"", ""write"", ""..."", ""can't"", ""text"", ""answers"", ""teachers""], [""one"", ""look"", ""forward"", ""beautifully"", ""handwritten"", ""notes"", ""get"", ""friends"", ""remember"", ""much"", ""emails"", ""text"", ""messages""], [""please"", ""let"", ""'s"", ""lower"", ""standards"", ""handwriting""]]","[[""VBD"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""CD"", ""POS"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""VBG"", ""RB""], [""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NFP"", ""NN"", "":"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ""], [""VBP"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""JJ""], [""NNS"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB""], [""VBZ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""VBN""], [""RB"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NFP"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NFP"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""CD"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""UH"", ""VB"", ""PRP"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN""]]",learned cursive grade school back 80 's n't stopped using since. WilliamH,"Odd for me to say this since I am (a) so deeply committed to technology and computers and type super fast (>100wpm), and (b) have really bad handwriting -- but I cannot imagine not writing in cursive. Writing in print is impossible. It is so slow as to be like using a early (not even late) generation dial-up modem. And for me at least, writing does stimulate thinking in a way that nothing else does. I took all my college and law school exams in writing, even though we were allowed to type them. For me at least, not being able to write really really fast would greatly lessen my capabilities. Brunella,"Tactile is necessary, along with virtual. Michael Cosgrove,"I disagree. For some of us, such as runners who go out in the sweltering heat for a long distance run in the desert, replenishing the salt and electrolytes lost during the run is a matter of health and recovery, not merely a flavoring option. I can understand that sedentary people and some chefs might blanch when the see me salting my food at a restaurant. But I'd like them to realize that I am doing so almost as a medicinal application and would prefer they reserve judgment until they've run a dozen miles in my shoes.",a place at the table,A1798-P,a place at the table,2,4,22514,9953236,"[[""disagree""], [""us"", ""runners"", ""go"", ""sweltering"", ""heat"", ""long"", ""distance"", ""run"", ""desert"", ""replenishing"", ""salt"", ""electrolytes"", ""lost"", ""run"", ""matter"", ""health"", ""recovery"", ""merely"", ""flavoring"", ""option""], [""understand"", ""sedentary"", ""people"", ""chefs"", ""might"", ""blanch"", ""see"", ""salting"", ""food"", ""restaurant""], [""'d"", ""like"", ""realize"", ""almost"", ""medicinal"", ""application"", ""would"", ""prefer"", ""reserve"", ""judgment"", ""'ve"", ""run"", ""dozen"", ""miles"", ""shoes""]]","[[""VBP""], [""PRP"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""MD"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""]]",disagree. us runners go sweltering heat long distance run desert replenishing salt electrolytes lost run matter health recovery merely flavoring option. understand sedentary people chefs might blanch see salting food restaurant. Nancy Lederman,"Count me a longtime fan of the 14th Amendment of the US Constitution, for its breadth and scope that encompasses the greatest of American values: not just defining citizenship, but setting forth states' obligations, due process, equal protection of the laws, This was the Amendment that required the states to follow the Bill of Rights. Brown v Board of Education, civil rights laws, privacy rulings, women's rights, gay rights, disability protections, they all flow from the 14th. Start tinkering, and you're risking a lot more than the status of some native-born children.",birthright citizenship,A4210-P,birthright citizenship,2,4,22515,15880150,"[[""count"", ""longtime"", ""fan"", ""14th"", ""amendment"", ""us"", ""constitution"", ""breadth"", ""scope"", ""encompasses"", ""greatest"", ""american"", ""values"", ""defining"", ""citizenship"", ""setting"", ""forth"", ""states"", ""obligations"", ""due"", ""process"", ""equal"", ""protection"", ""laws"", ""amendment"", ""required"", ""states"", ""follow"", ""bill"", ""rights""], [""brown"", ""v"", ""board"", ""education"", ""civil"", ""rights"", ""laws"", ""privacy"", ""rulings"", ""women"", ""'s"", ""rights"", ""gay"", ""rights"", ""disability"", ""protections"", ""flow"", ""14th""], [""start"", ""tinkering"", ""'re"", ""risking"", ""lot"", ""status"", ""native"", ""born"", ""children""]]","[[""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""JJS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""RP"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""NNPS""], [""NNP"", ""IN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""POS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""VBG"", ""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NNS""]]",count longtime fan 14th amendment us constitution breadth scope encompasses greatest american values defining citizenship setting forth states obligations due process equal protection laws amendment required states follow bill rights. brown v board education civil rights laws privacy rulings women 's rights gay rights disability protections flow 14th. start tinkering 're risking lot status native born children,"[""place"", ""table""]",place table,0,0;;;;

Anita,"I would no more declaw a cat than fly to the moon on gossamer wings! There's another option, which some consider to be more humane, and that is to cut the muscles or whatever that allow the cat to retract its claws. They just flop in or out, depending on the position of the cat. PLEASE explain to me why this form of torture is more humane than declawing. I could never maim, hurt, torture or kill any animal. My cat is a strictly indoor creature, she has all of her claws and a nice big scratching post/cat tree. She has NEVER ONCE scratched on anything but that. I taught her to do that. It is NOT impossible to train a cat!",your cat,A842-P,your cat,2,4,22519,17020896,"[[""would"", ""declaw"", ""cat"", ""fly"", ""moon"", ""gossamer"", ""wings""], [""'s"", ""another"", ""option"", ""consider"", ""humane"", ""cut"", ""muscles"", ""whatever"", ""allow"", ""cat"", ""retract"", ""claws""], [""flop"", ""depending"", ""position"", ""cat""], [""please"", ""explain"", ""form"", ""torture"", ""humane"", ""declawing""], [""could"", ""never"", ""maim"", ""hurt"", ""torture"", ""kill"", ""animal""], [""cat"", ""strictly"", ""indoor"", ""creature"", ""claws"", ""nice"", ""big"", ""scratching"", ""post"", ""cat"", ""tree""], [""never"", ""scratched"", ""anything""], [""taught""], [""impossible"", ""train"", ""cat""]]","[[""MD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""VBZ"", ""DT"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""WDT"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""UH"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""VBG""], [""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""VBD""], [""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN""]]",would declaw cat fly moon gossamer wings. George,"Privatization of state asserts means that German businessmen can buy those asserts at a fraction of their real value and make Greece a German colony. Lachman has served the interests of the world's financial elites whose motto (Adam Smith, bk 3) is ""everything for ourselves and nothing for other people."" Those German businessmen and firms spent hundreds of millions of euros bribing Greek officials to buy German weapons including a set of submarines that never went to sea and are now rusting ashore--Merkel's masters want them paid for though the debt be odious. A major NY bank enabled a Greek government to disguise huge borrowings as investments; those debts too are odious. There's a story: Merkel went to Greece;" the customs official asked """"Nationality
post: " Merkel answered """"German."""" """"Occupation"""" asked the customs officer
ori_id: I'm just here for the weekend.""""Lachman warns """"leaving the euro would almost surely result in a massive run on the Greek banks
new_topic: which would plunge the country into economic and financial chaos."""" Where does he think Greece is now? Oh yes
label: reparations for the German occupation of Greece during WWII?""

author: Responsible Bob,"The pathway to a career in medicine is designed to benefit specific areas of medicine. To be considered for admission to medical school, candidates must spend significant time and effort on research. This results in substantial free labor for tens of thousands of researchers. Also this effort is focused on research rather than more specifically to areas such as serving the community, which has a lesser role. International medical school graduates also spend months and sometimes longer demonstrating their skills to obtain a residency position. This is another area that can be abused as the stakes are high and there are few protections against abuses. Health professional associations and corporations preparing candidates for standardized tests have a great design that benefits them well, but fails to deliver the health professionals needed.",college students,A495-P,college students,2,4,22523,5445604,"[[""pathway"", ""career"", ""medicine"", ""designed"", ""benefit"", ""specific"", ""areas"", ""medicine""], [""considered"", Old Doc,"The ACA is what we have and what we were able to generate. While it is far from perfect and single-payer would likely be better, we need to try and make it work. Obama should get some credit for making any in-roads in this nasty, contentious climate. And older healthcare advancements came together in piece-meal improvements so there is reason to hope we can move towards single-payer, or least incremental improvement and coverage.",obamacare,A1445-P,obamacare,2,4,22525,10096616,"[[""aca"", ""able"", ""generate""], [""far"", ""perfect"", ""single"", ""payer"", ""would"", ""likely"", ""better"", ""need"", ""try"", ""make"", ""work""], [""obama"", ""get"", ""credit"", ""making"", ""roads"", ""nasty"", ""contentious"", ""climate""], [""older"", ""healthcare"", ""advancements"", ""came"", ""together"", ""piece"", ""meal"", ""improvements"", ""reason"", ""hope"", ""move"", ""towards"", ""single"", ""payer"", ""least"", ""incremental"", ""improvement"", ""coverage""]]","[[""NN"", ""JJ"", ""VB""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""JJR"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""VB""], [""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""JJR"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""IN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",aca able generate. far perfect single payer would likely better need try make work. obama get credit making roads nasty contentious climate. older healthcare advancements came together piece meal improvements reason hope move towards single payer least incremental improvement coverage,"[""college"", ""student""]",college student,1,0;;;;
